results.title: The World's greatest cricketers. Part 1
results.creator_credit: Span Pictures, Instyle Promotions and Derek Hanlon
results.brief_description: In 1987, Sally Jones interviewed three of the world’s most famous cricketers; Imran Khan, Sir Richard Hadlee and Australia’s Allan Border. With introductions by ex-England Captain Bob Willis, viewers are given an opportunity to share in the public and private life of these legendary sportsmen. Imran talks about his his status as a “pop star” cult hero type in Pakistan; Sir Richard Hadlee of his family’s involvement in New Zealand cricket; while Allan Border shows what he can do on the golf course as well as the cricket pitch.

results.title: The World's best known dicks
results.brief_description: Presented by John Thursday - Private Eye (Thom Depres), this documentary contains many wonderful excerpts and trailers from some of those classic detective films of the 30s and 40s, many of which were based on novels. Includes Peter Lorre in “Mysterious Mr Moto” (1938) and “Mr Moto’s last warning” (1939), Basil Rathbone in “The Adventures of Sherlock Holmes” (1939), William Powell as Philo Vance in “The Kennel murder case” (1933), Ralph Byrd as Dick Tracy in “Dick Tracy meets gruesome” (1947), Ronald Colman as Bulldog Drummond and many more of your favourite stars and co-stars, sleuths and villains in all manner of mysteries and mayhem.

results.title: The Working parent
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “PGR Series”.
Combining work with parenthood provides numerous pressures for working parents. P.G.R. looks at some of these problems, including house duties, mother’s re-entry to the workforce, workplace issues affecting women’s rights, managing chores while caring for children, and becoming a house husband. We talk to a number of people from a variety of backgrounds who have managed to balance the competing needs of their careers and their children.

results.title: The Work That Was. Parts 1 & 2
results.brief_description: Who Pays the Price? (Sydney, 1979, 30 min.): Looks at the possible social effects of technological change in the context of Australia’s economic system. “Futures” (Sydney, 1979, 30 min.): Looks at the decline of labour intensive manufacturing industries in Australia, unemployment in country towns, and the prospects of the coming mineral boom.

results.title: The Work prejudice film
results.creator_credit: Sandler Institutional Films, Allan Frank Sandler and Ray Rivas
results.brief_description: Investigates the stereotypes surrounding the world of work relevant to an American situation. Documentation and humour are used to motivate the young person who faces 25 to 45 years in the workforce. Narrated by Robert Vaughn. Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels.

results.title: The Work of the World Health Organisation
results.creator_credit: Janine Hamel-Minne, World Health Organisation and United Nations
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Man Alive”.
Traces the history of the World Health Organisation from early attempts to develop an international program for prevention of epidemics to the current promotion of health. Also gives an overall view of the work and activities of the Organisation.

results.title: The Work of the kidneys. - 2nd. ed
results.creator_credit: Frank V Robinson, Charles L. Finance and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “Biology program. Unit 4. Physiology”.
Examines the importance of the kidneys as regulators of the body’s internal environment. Shows the functions of the kidney’s major parts and the relationships of these parts to each other as well as describing the physiological mechanisms by which the kidneys control the volume and composition of body fluids.
